s.text: That system, the creation of the management guru W. Edwards Deming, replaces overtly bureaucratic control with self-managing work teams and an emphasis on a "common vision."
Deb is blunt about why she likes the status quo, despite the stress of arranging child care: "At work I can do more of what I want.
Does that mean that stressed-out mothers and fathers are finding better ways to balance their home and work lives?
That system, the creation of the management guru W. Edwards Deming, replaces overtly bureaucratic control with self-managing work teams and an emphasis on a "common vision."
Deb is blunt about why she likes the status quo, despite the stress of arranging child care: "At work I can do more of what I want.
Does that mean that stressed-out mothers and fathers are finding better ways to balance their home and work lives?
The truth is that home hasn't suddenly become work.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.

But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.

Mario, a workaholic whose low-level job is stacking and loading boxes, loves his kids but can't wait for his shift with them to end: "It's very stressful mentally, and I get sick of hearing myself scream."
They've "outsourced" functions that used to be part of their responsibility (baby sitters, tutors, camps), creating a fragmented regimen.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
But somewhere along the way, they've--we've--also lost all patience for kids.
Employees at every level of Amerco fit Hochschild's profile of distracted parenthood.

This mid-19 th century godsend--whose letter is quoted in At Odds: Women and the Family in America From the Revolution to the Present , by Carl Degler--was an unusual recruit to the enterprise of child rearing: She neither romanticized her mission nor vented her frustration on her charges.
But Spock was not, pace his critics, a permissive advocate of giving the child real power or of giving parents an easy break.
That system, the creation of the management guru W. Edwards Deming, replaces overtly bureaucratic control with self-managing work teams and an emphasis on a "common vision."
